comment.text:
Our server Brandy was fantastic. She made a great wine selection and continued to check on us throughout the night. The lump crab ale was the best starter I've ever tried. 
The sole was delicious. It had a succotash that was flavored perfectly. Will definitely come back in the future.

This is a true 5+ Star restaurant. 

My wife and I ate at Aria last night (3/20/21) for our 5 year anniversary. We arrived about two minutes before our reservation and were immediately greeted and brought to our table. The atmosphere was nice and quiet, well spaced out and with some really neat decor. Could tell right away this was likely going to be a solid experience. Jordan was our server and was extremely polite, professional and attentive. 

We each had a glass of champagne to start our celebration. Presentation by Jordan was exceptional. He poured a taste first then poured our glasses at the table. I then had a pre-dinner cocktail, The High Five. It was a solid bourbon drink. 

My wife and I decided (as we usually do) to share several things.  The pre-dinner bread was to die for. No extra butter or olive oil needed. It's perfect as is. We started with the beef tenderloin starter. It was amazing. Then we had the romaine hearts salad which was also delicious. Nice and light but plenty of flavor. Next we had the sashimi appetizer. Again...delicious. For our main we had the pork with seared broccoli. It was perfectly cooked, perfectly seasoned and simply delicious. It turned out we had the perfect amount of food. For our dinner wine we had a bottle of 2013 Fiddlehead Pinot Noir. Again...excellent presentation and they used proper Pinot Noir glasses. 

I have eaten at a fairly decent amount of nice restaurants in Atlanta. I'm going to go ahead and say it, and my wife agrees, Aria deserves a spot in at least our top 5. 

Will be back for sure.

We went here for our first anniversary ! Y'all ask for Sandra when you go...she will take care of you! Their food was lick your fingers, smacking type of good, but since we were at an upscale establishment; I didn't do those type of homely things #ImALadywithABlackNapkinOverMyLap....but that's how good it was. Go see for yourself friend

photos.caption: Grilled tenderloin of beef, Korean bbq sauce, cilantro
Spiced bourbon glazed Chilean salmon, haricot vert, zucchini, fingerling potatoes
Breast of duck, honey spice glaze, fuji apples, savoy cabbage, carrots, natural jus

comment.text:
Highlights:
Delicious food, sexy atmosphere, awesome vibe, friendly service, covid compliant 

We got:
- Duck confit, chickpea fritters as starters and they were freaking delicious. The duck is super juicy, crispy, cooked perfectly. 
- scallops were super salty... cooked well but too much salt that overtook the texture and overall dish. 
- steak cooked perfectly to medium rare. What I HATE about steakhouses is, I ask for medium rare and often times I get medium. I asked for medium rare!!! 
- lemon pound cake, you may say is not special enough to get it at a restaurant... but I loved that boldness to serve this so I said what the heck. Show me what you got and they definitely showed it to me! Amazing. The best lemon pound cake ever with rich ice cream on the side. Totally get it. 

Overall, delicious (but slightly small portion) food/place to treat yo self. Really friendly informative waitress. I'd say 9.5 Gryffindor points out of 10.

photos.caption: Pan Seared New Bedford Jumbo Sea Scallops

comment.text:
I love Aria, food is always consistent, friendly servers, they can do subs on the tasting menu (great for people who HATE certain things like lamb or goat cheese). Reservations aren't too difficult yet the dining room is always lively.

Why minus 1 star? They have a perfectly usable parking lot but they have a forced valet system. In this day and age, no one carries cash and it is always such an annoying experience to pull up and realize someone is going to be driving my car 2 feet to an empty spot I drove past on my way up to the valet, then I have to awkwardly leave them empty-handed because I just don't carry cash. Who pays with cash? Either get rid of the useless valet system OR set it up with a QR code for digital tipping, etc. If you intend to grow to a younger clientele understand your new, younger client base doesn't carry cash.

The service and food is excellent! My favorite is the warm chèvre cheesecake! It's hands down the best cheesecake I've had! The crab cake had generous amounts of crab meat. The pork belly is also a pretty generous portion size and very crispy. The staff is also very enthusiastic and helpful!

The fiancé and I came here for our 8th anniversary dinner.

Atmosphere is nice and intimate. By that, I mean you do sit fairly close with other patrons so don't expect a ton of privacy. After our meal, I knew the table to our right were on a date and table to our left were a group of friends who hadn't seen each other in a while. Also it is really LOUD. With everyone so close together, you almost have to yell at the person across from you for you to hear them.

Service was good. Attentive. Great recommendations and  friendly.

Our meal included:

- Roasted Brussels Sprouts: A low point of our meal. Nothing special that I don't normally cook at home.

- Pork belly: Delectable bites of super fatty pork. No seasoning really so it was bland and fatty with some sweetness from the jam, which was interesting. 

- Rainbow trout: My entree. Excellent sear on the fish and everything was seasoned really well. My fiancé who doesn't like fish even enjoyed it. The sauce purée was delicious.

- Beef short rib: My fiancé's entree. Tender and well seasoned. Good but not as memorable as my entree.

- Lemon pound cake: If you enjoy sweet/tangy desserts, this is perfect! Very strong lemon flavor and aroma. I could've eaten two orders of this alone. So good!

We also ordered several craft cocktails and unfortunately, our drinks all tasted very watered down without any real discernible flavors. I would stay with the wines next time.

Overall, we had an enjoyable evening but this just wasn't a place that impressed or intrigued me enough to warrant a return visit. Next!

photos.caption: short rib of beef, green ola farms squashes, pearl onions, potato purée
mountain trout, snowpeas, pattypan squash, baby carrots, basil

comment.text:
Aria has a lovely atmosphere. The interior is dark and romantic, with mirrors and beautiful light fixtures. 

The appetizers we ordered were really good and honestly way better than the main courses. I was kind of underwhelmed by the main courses. I went a few months ago and I'm not sure if these are still on the menu, but we had the soft shell crab and lobster risotto for our appetizers. So good! The soft shell crab had a great crispy texture and was served over a salad with asian flavors. The lobster appetizer was creamy and buttery. 

For the entrees, we had the short rib beef and the filet mignon. It wasn't really anything special to me. It was good, but not super memorable. I probably wouldn't order those again. I felt kind of let down because our appetizers had great flavor. 

We also shared a bottle of $96 white wine that went wonderfully with the light and fresh flavors. Definitely a splurge but it made it a great date night.

What made this place lacking to me was our service that night was very inattentive. Also a bug flew into one of our wine glasses, and when we told the server, she just drained the bug out and returned us the glass of wine that had the bug in it. It was an expensive bottle, and I think it would have been much better if she offered to replace that glass with a new glass of wine. 

A plus side was that valet parking was great and the parking attendant was very nice. 

If you are in the Atlanta area, I would say just try out this place once for date night. It really is lovely. Hopefully you get better service than we did though.

Fancy Buckhead restaurant
We came here for an anniversary dinner. The staff was super attentive and the restaurant is very beautiful. We did feel a little rushed to order. They have very attentive service here so it was hard to tell if they were being super attentive or trying to move tables. They sat us by a very loud group having a work dinner. There is a small dining room and we were sat close to this group. The cocktails are delicious. The wine menu is extensive. The food was very good. They brought out a special dessert for us that had Happy 3rd anniversary written In chocolate on it. It was a nice experience. The only reason I'm giving a four instead of five because we felt rushed and the table by us was very loud. Also the wine list is super high end and I would appreciate some more basic choices. Overall a very nice place for a special occasion.
We had my husband's birthday with kids there. Nice atmosphere, great food and great service. Good memory for our family.

What a wonderful place to dine for my birthday. For weekends, you must have reservations as the restaurant is operating at a smaller capacity due to Covid. Great safety precautions were taken, all employees were wearing masks and gloves, which we saw them change often.  Customer service was top notch, from our attentive server Batina, to the knowledgeable sommelier Andrew, to the assistant manager who checked on us often. We opted for the 7 course, preselected meal option, and it did not disappoint. I wish I could remember all the courses, but they were all delicious. 
The atmosphere was intimate with low lighting and classic decor. This is the place to go for a romantic fine dining experience.
Top to bottom amazing. Love the redesign to modernize the restaurant and would recommend the a la carte or tasting menu to anyone.

I've been here a few times and great food, but I noticed there is no real diversity in the staff. I also witness some less than stellar treatment of the staff at the hands of the long time manager. Hopefully next time I return they'll be more servers of color.

We came here the night we got married at the courthouse, and returned for a belated one year anniversary dinner. Needless to say, this restaurant has a special place in our hearts. Both dining experiences have been everything we could have asked for and beyond. The photos are from our last visit a couple months ago shortly after they reopened (we were one of two tables on the patio spaced far apart and all waiters wore masks and gloves).

Everything we have tried here has been incredible. The lobster mac n cheese is one of my favorites - sooo good, with sizable chunks of lobster. I was sad when it was gone. The beet salad is also fantastic.

You honestly can't go wrong with any of the items on their (changing daily) menu. Ambiance and service are absolutely fantastic. They also have some great mixologists. Highly recommend for a date night or special occasion!

photos.caption: Lobster mac and cheese - sooo good

comment.text: we all loved it. food was great. but the people we're the best part. fast, kind, attentive, fun, etc. we we're very impressed. and they had great spicy margaritas which are my favorite.

Wonderful date night place. Service is excellent. The bar and wine list are solid and fairly complete. Corkage is $25, towards the top end but acceptable. The reason you come to aria is for the food. 

We always pick a few snacks for cocktails. Be sure to try the Korean beef and black truffle burrata. For first courses, all the salads rock, but you're probably not here for that. Get the yellowtail!  Amazing. Always. 

Personally I love the lamb loin. If you are a short rib person, it's good. The duck confit is done differently, and we haven't cared for it. 

The sweets (a small nosh plate) at the end of the meal were terrible. First thing was some kind of nut merengue, followed by a super sweet nutrigrain bar and then some super sweet chocolate thing.  Yuck. Won't do that again.

photos.caption: The cheesecake is the most popular dessert.
Don't get the sweets unless you LOVE sweets. OMG. So sweet I nearly spit two of the three out.

comment.text: Cozy cottage with amazing wine selection..cocktails and diverse menu. I know Cali well but was thrown off by the French and Italian wine list no issues a great sommelier got us 2 great wines...menu too varied to describe but for me the duck was perfectly done and veg was super tasty. Service was on point and overall the restaurant was a great value for a business dinner. We were well fed and we'll taken care of.

Excellent ambiance and service. We had beef skewer (this was ok), pork belly (this was great) and hamachi appetizer. For main course we had duck breast and short ribs. They were all good but nothing particularly exciting. Pork belly was the favorite out of everything we had.

photos.caption: Painted Hills Ranch Natural Beef Short Rib
Duck Pan Roasted Breast of Farm Raised Duck

comment.text:
Had a lovely Friday date night at Aria! My boyfriend and I dined here for the first time, and I'm already thinking about Aria for our next date night. The service was great, the dining room is classic yet very romantic with dimmed lighting, seating was thoughtful due to Covid, and the food was phenomenal. We had the lobster with puréed potatoe for our starter. I had the scallops as my entree and my boyfriend enjoyed the sole. 
Lemon pound cake for dessert, perfect sweet tangy balance. With great food & a wine selection that's top notch, I will be returning very soon!

Aria is a mainstay on the Atlanta fine dining scene with good reason, they deliver a quality experience with congenial hospitality and aplomb. While efforts have been made to appeal to a younger generation of diner, Aria clearly remains a favorite of a more established crowd. The food is tasty and broadly appealing; though rays of creativity shine through at times, parts of the savory menu are somewhat banal. Don't miss Chef Kathryn King's desserts, which are uniquely composed and amazingly delicious. The beverage program is another highlight; excellent wine and cocktail list. Overall a very pleasant and solid experience!

Atmosphere
- Recently renovated and modernized; the space retains an upscale feel without being overly stuffy and formal.
- Great bar area at the front, though the tight quarters meant it wasn't fully utilized in Covid times. Would absolutely go back for more casual, small bites in the bar plus the beverage list, a winning combination.
- Business casual was generally the dress, jacket neither required nor out of place.
- Parking entrance is off East Paces, not particularly well marked. Early in the evening, it wasn't hard to get a spot. No valet or parking fees.

Food
The cuisine at Aria is marked by quality ingredients and thoughtful execution. While flavorful, the menu offers little in the way of unexpected twists and turns. The flip side is that there are agreeable options for most tastes, including those not looking to go far afield.

- Shareable Snacks ($8-12): These were all 3-4 bites and as the name suggests, easy to split. For a party of four, we ordered four items, which was perhaps even too much. The snacks were a highlight, with bold flavors and a global influence. Especially enjoyed the pork belly; beautiful camerlization and tasty chutney.
- Starters ($16-20): The name is a bit of a misnomer, as these are very generous portions. Our group of four split two, after which we became quite full after this and the snacks. One dish is good to share for two people. The duck confit was crispy and moist, with a very generous portion.
- Entrees ($32-48): A bit of a mixed experience. The trout and scallops were more uniquely composed; the short rib, while flavorful and well presented, was very generic and something we have made at home many times.
- Dessert ($10-12): Wow, this was excellent. Feeling quite full, tried one option to get the jist. The lemon pound cake was moist and delicious, with the accompaniments (amazing in their own right) jazzing up the flavor and making for a very memorable conclusion.

Returning, I think the ideal meal would consist of either a bunch of shareable snacks and an entree, or one starter split for two and an entree. The dessert is excellent, make sure you leave room! Aria does not skimp on the portions, so plan accordingly. A tasting menu ($86/person) was also available so long as the entire table partakes.

Beverage
One of the best parts of the experience, starting with cocktails. Really enjoyed the Figure Drawings (Peppercorn Gin, Velvet Falernum, Grapefruit, Lime - $14) to start, nicely balanced.

The wine list is well-selected, with a strong array of options across regions at reasonable price points (most are $60-150).  Many of the selections are more unique, but are mixed in with some better known names. Our interaction with the sommelier was friendly and positive, yielding a strong recommendation for our tastes. We really enjoyed the Bruliam Soberanes Vineyard Pinot Noir ($118) with the meal. Wines by the glass were also great (most $15-18/gl).

Service
-Very hospitable and welcoming, not even a whiff of condescension.
-Attentiveness waned a touch as the dining room filled up, but overall a great job.

photos.caption: grilled tender beef (korean bbq sauce, lime, cilantro)
crisped berkshire pork belly with apple-cranberry chutney
12 month old manchego (apricot jam, walnuts, toasted baguette)
crisped duck confit (endive, fennel, arugula, raspberries, duck jus)
short rib of beef (zucchini, yellow squash, snow peas, whipped potatoes)

comment.text:
Fine dining at its finest!  Absolute and sincere compliments to the chef. The appetizers, salads, entrees, and desserts - all delicious, fresh, and beautifully plated.  And everything that passed by us on the way to other tables also looked excellent. The atmosphere and ambiance were elegant. Everyone here was having a great time! 

The menu changes daily, so there is always something new and fresh to try. Again, compliments to the chef for the creativity required to invent a new menu every day. 

The staff here obviously have some kind of formal training in fine dining. They were all knowledgeable, friendly, polite, and knew exactly what they were doing.

If you are thinking about going here, make your reservation now! I called about a week in advance to make a reservation. They had no availability from 5pm to 9pm on a Saturday. Fortunately, the host was able to re-arrange some things and squeeze us in. Excellent service if you ask me! 

This is undoubtedly an upscale place. I felt under-dressed wearing a button-down shirt, a nice wool zip-up, and a pair of dark jeans. Next time, I will change to slacks and maybe a sport coat (and there certainly will be a next time).

You must use their complimentary valet parking; there is no self park option. The entire parking lot is maybe 30 cars, so the valet doesn't move your car more than a couple of feet. It seems to me like an unnecessary formality. 

All in all, I was incredibly pleased with our experience and I will absolutely be back.

Wow! Simply wow! 

The service was great. Every one in the room contributed to the flow of the restaurant ensuring all books and crannies were checked. 

As for the food, every dish we order in our six course meal had no issues.
If you're testing this place for the first time and plan on sharing, they will offer to split your meal in the kitchen for you. TRUST the chef! If certain meats need to be cook at a certain temperature, let the chef take the wheel! I promise you that you will not regret it! 

Certain restaurants in this type of area may have you leaving hungry with a high cost bill but this place has its portion packed down! Please check it out! 

The plates are affordable ...ranges around $15-50.

My wife and I had dinner at Aria for our wedding anniversary.  Everything was perfect.  From the time we pulled up the service was over the top - the valet, the hostesses, the bartender, and our waiter, Kim.  The food was all fantastic too, but what stood out the most was the service.  It was amazing and unlike anything we have experienced in years.  In fact, my wife and I could not remember when we last had such incredible service.  We had crab cakes, salads, sole, filet mignon, truffle whipped potatoes, and the warm cheesecake for desert.  The wine was perfectly paired with the help of Kim.  The food was all really good.  It looked amazing and tasted even better.  It was a great overall experience.  We highly recommend Aria and we look forward to going back.

We were visiting from out of town and wanted to go to a nice restaurant. It was my birthday  weekend and I just wanted to  enjoy some good food. I found this place online and tried it out. Made a reservation and arrived early and we were seated within minutes. It's a cozy resturant located about 29 mins from downtown Atlanta. Our waiter was amazing he answered all of our questions . He made some recommendations and explained the menu to us. The drinks were made well. The food was fantastic. The portion size was perfect. This place is well priced . I would definitely recommend it to others.

The meal started on a bad foot. When we made our reservation, we asked for a private table. Our previous review shows that we didn't like how close we sat near others. Well, still no more private.

Once seated, we waited 10 minutes before our server came by with water and our drink orders. I was starving so I put in a couple of starters and she suggested we put in our whole order. When she returned, we put in our whole order. 2 of our 3 apps came and they were fine, under salted. They must've read my last review because the Brussels shrank in size substantially. Then the issue. Our server, Kaitlin, disappeared. Approximately 35 minutes later and the tables around us had their food. We flagged down a different server for bread. Another server for more drinks. Kaitlin disappeared.

Finally, we got the manager and he came by with our crab cakes. Kaitlin rushed out beside him, blaming the kitchen for the food delay, not acknowledging her absence.

Ultimately, the manager took off the crab cakes and our dessert but the meal was underwhelming, under salted and undersized. 

So sad that this institution has gone down.

Was so looking forward to this meal. We were celebrating 2 birthdays. The place was really nice from an atmosphere perspective but i have to say i was not impressed. We started with the pork belly and beef skewers. The pork belly was delish but the beef was tasteless without the sauce. Sauce was good but the beef was lackluster. We all ordered something different and a few dishes were flat and the other 2 were ok. We had birthday desserts and the lemon pound cake and the sorbets. The cake was good but sorbets were ok. We had Moscow mules to start and couldn't taste the alcohol. Wish i could say it was memorable but it wasnt.
Best chef driven restaurant in Atlanta year after year. I don't know why we keep trying all these new restaurants and ordering chicken because it's the only thing that seems edible.

Located in the heart of Buckhead, Aria was our unanimous choice for our family's Christmas Eve dinner while visiting Atlanta over the holidays. 

Our evening started with Aria's convenient valet parking, a cheerful and inviting greeting as we checked in and two hours of outstanding 5-star service by Brandi, our totally professional server. 

You've gotta love the classy but relaxed ambiance of this jewel on E. Paces Ferry. The spot-lighted jeweled dog sculptures will immediately catch your eye as you walk past the small, intimate bar with just a half dozen bar stools. 

The dining areas are very tastefully done with a unique, almost jellyfish-like chandelier gently illuminating the dining room.  Aria even has arm rest pillows positioned beside the diners on the leather upholstered bench seating against the wall...a comfort first in my years of fine dining. 

Christmas Eve turned out to be a carnivorous night for our family of six with only two appetizers going the way of fish and foul. The Lump Crab Cake was delicious while the Crisped Boneless Duck Confit w/ red cabbage and applewood smoked bacon w/ natural jus was absolutely over the top...a best-in-class preparation of duck. 

For entrees, we ordered 3 orders of the Short Ribs of Beef, two portions of the Slow Braised Berkshire Pork and a singular Black Angus Filet Mignon.  Paired with a bottle of 2015 Pouilly-Fuisse and a 2011 Casanova di Nero's Brunello di Montalcino...Wow...what a flavorful feast. 

For dessert, we shared the Warm Chocolate Cheesecake with softly whipped cream and the Lemon Pound Cake with lemon custard and pineapple compote. Both plates completely wowed us. 

Our Christmas Eve experience at Aria was void of any Clark W. Griswold disasters...and exceeded our expectations in every way.  It was clearly a family holiday highlight...aria earns the solid nickel.

photos.caption: Simple entry steps off E Paces Ferry Rd.
Lemon Pound Cake w/ lemon custard and pineapple compote.

comment.text: Absolutely wonderful, everything was cooked perfectly, my boyfriend ordered short did and it was super delicate and the vegetables were tender. The filet minon was a little undercooked and i ordered medium rare. We got the chocolate chews kale for dessert and it was the best dessert we've had, overall, if you're looking for a fancy restaurant with expensive yet somewhat affordable prices for a special occasion, this is the place to go

I called prior to ask if the restaurant was appropriate for me as I was dining alone while on business. Mercedez was so accommodating and ensured that I'd have a comfortable and amazing time. She was right. (Love her!) 

Try the scallops- fabulous
Try the arugula with fennel and citrus dressing. Life changing
Orders a Red Zinfandel that was perfectly dry and Whitney Bottled what was left for me. 

Whitney was fabulous and so attentive. We chatted about the menu and life and I felt like I wasn't dining alone.  

Intimidate and relaxing ambiance. Will be back

Xo
Melineh

Came here for dinner on a Thursday without reservation, luckily, we don't have to wait. The restaurant is bigger than what it looks like from the outside. However, upon walking into the restaurant, I immediately noticed the noise level was really high for a nice restaurant. 

The decor is nice inside, like in an old movie. I like the design of the light in the middle of the dinning room. And was really happy that there is no table directly underneath the sharp pointy edge of the light. I'd be too scared to sit there lol

Onto the food, we ordered crispy pork belly with cranberry sauce, foie gras, Duck confit, venison entree. Everything was tasty. I especially liked the crispy pork belly and the duck confit. 

Overall, a good dining experience. I really wish Yelp can do a half star rating too because Aria is a good 4.5 stars!

photos.caption: Duck confit was good. Really good value too!
Crispy pork belly is so good! Get it!

comment.text:
Aria is a popular fine dining restaurant in Buckhead. It opened March 2000 and is owned by the same group as Canoe. Located in a small white building surrounded by hedges and a big tree, it's easy to miss this restaurant on the corner of East Paces Ferry Road and Maple Drive. The entrance is in the back next to the valet stand. Valet is complimentary.

The restaurant isn't terribly big, consisting of a small bar and a single dining room with two sections of seating. The interior design is nice, but also a bit strange. From the entrance, you have to walk through this curtain of heavy beads through the intimate bar/lounge to the white-colored dining room filled with classical columns and avant-garde decor. There's a bizarre light fixture in the middle of the dining room which vaguely resembles a tentacled sea creature. There are two jewel-encrusted dog sculptures on either side of the steps leading to the dining room. The monochrome floral patterns on the upholstery is beautiful.

The atmosphere is cozy, romantic, and intimate. There are white tablecloths and candles at every table. Seating against the wall is snug and you can hear the conversations of those sitting next to you and vice versa. If you don't like this, you can try to request to be seated elsewhere when making your reservation.

Reservations are recommended. Aria is on OpenTable and has offered 1,000-point reservations at times. Take advantage if you can.

The restaurant's menu changes nightly. The cuisine is New American with an emphasis on slow-cooked and sustainable foods made from high quality, local and regional ingredients. On any given night, the menu will feature about 10 starters and 10 entrees. Most starters run about $10-15 each and entrees $30-35 each. There's also a pre-set tasting menu that runs $68 per person. This is less expensive than comparable Atlanta restaurants such as Bacchanalia and Restaurant Eugene ($85 each).

I love tasting menus, so that's what we went with. At Aria, each course of the tasting menu is described on the printed menu. There are no substitutions or optional courses. Accommodations can be made for those with food allergies. Here's a rundown of what I had, course by course:

* Bread: House Focaccia
* Course 1: Creamless Celery Root Soup - black truffles, Parmigiano Reggiano
* Course 2: Crisped Tempura Octopus - roasted butternut squash, roasted peanuts, Fuji apple, mizuna, frisee, candied ginger vinaigrette
* Course 3: Blue Ridge Mountain Trout - butter fondue, melted leeks, Hakurei turnips, baby carrots, fingerling potatoes
* Course 4: Crisped South Carolina Quail - shaved Brussels sprouts, applewood smoked bacon, grain mustard vinaigrette
* Course 5: Pan Roasted Loin of Venison - charred broccoli, Hakurei turnips, baby carrots, pearl onion petals
* Course 6: Chocolate Espresso Cake - almond toffee ice cream

Unlike other fine dining restaurants, there are no amuse-bouches or gifts from the chef at Aria. Just one bread course and then the items listed on the prix fixe menu.

The food was fantastic. The House Focaccia bread was exceptional. It was freshly baked, warm, soft, and herby. Also a little bit oily, it was served pre-sliced into rectangular strips.

The Creamless Celery Root Soup was delicious. It tasted similar to a cream of mushroom soup, but lighter. The hint of truffles was absolutely mouthwatering.

The Crisped Tempura Octopus was my least favorite dish of the night. While the octopus meat was fresh, its consistency felt relatively soggy or mushy and the thin layer of tempura batter wasn't crispy. The rest of the dish was great though, from the julienned apple to the delicate mizuna and frisee greens. The delightful ginger vinaigrette tied it together.

The Blue Ridge Mountain Trout was very good. The skin was perfectly succulent and crispy. This dish normally came with a lobster bisque sauce, but due to my food allergy, the chef specially prepared a butter and cheese fondue sauce instead. I particularly enjoyed the tender baby carrots and sweet and fruity Hakurei turnips.

The Crisped South Carolina Quail was phenomenal -- one of the best-prepared quails I've had to date. The half-quail meat was juicy and flavorful. The little bird had been expertly deboned. The Brussels salad and pork belly bits were icing on top of the proverbial cake.

The Pan Roasted Loin of Venison was excellent. The venison was cooked medium rare. The slices of meat were moist, luscious, and flavorful.

The Chocolate Espresso Cake was superb. Rich yet airy. I had to eat the almond toffee ice cream quickly before it melted away.

Service was good though a bit slow. Coats were checked and silverware and plates were changed in a timely manner. We liked our server and the other staff were nothing but polite and courteous. However, course pacing could have been better and we had extended waits on the check.

Overall, Aria is a terrific restaurant. Do the tasting menu.

Went to Aria twice in December 2021 - once for a date night and once with friends.  Liked it both times..  Bread Service is amazing and menu is seasonal so got to try a bunch of menu items.  Things I ate - burrata, crab cake, beet salad, filet, sea bass, chocolate cheesecake.  Crab cake exceeded expectations.  Also loved the filet.  Chocolate cheesecake was eh - I bet they have better desserts.  Service is always great and valet is convenient.

I've been here a few times now and enjoyed my time here every time.

The atmosphere is quite unique. They have a few controversial pieces here but the main dining room is actually quite austere with the chandelier being the main attraction. Other than that, it's white on white with white table cloths and walls. 

Their bar is quite small and located right at the entrance but it's nicely stocked.

For mu drink I went safe and got my default Manhattan - pretty decent. 

App: smoked salmon - ery good. Not a fan of creme fraiche all over the place though. 

My maine dish: Roasted Venison Loin - a bit on the dry side unfortunately. My companion went with duck and I stole most of it off his plate. Note to self: If you want it, get it - even if you both order the same dish! 

Overall: good service, pleasant atmosphere, valet, random art which is always fun! 
I will be back again
The service and food were top notch. The salads, beef shareable were great. I had the scallops which were so tender and delicious. We will definitely be back.

My husband know I'm a foodie and my birthday is my "holiday " do after a few surprises he informed me he had reservations for Aria. 

Neither of us could decide on what we wanted to order so we got the 7 course tasting meal.

How was it‽ PERFECT!!!!

photos.caption: mountain trout( huh how a fish climb a mountain) fennel carrots and asparagus.
duck foie gras with cherry beans
I had risotto with chanterelle mushrooms, Parmesan and gruyere is for me hands down DA BOMB!!!
I love soft shell crab but the mix of basil, fennel, cilantro and a acid mix was awesome!!!
My husband had the lobster with purée potatoes and peas.
Yellowtail sashimi (the citrus and arugula set it off).

comment.text:
We had a very interesting experience here. Showed up for our reservation at 8:00pm and didn't get seated until 9:00pm. It was a bit frustrating because why even make reservations? Our initial hostess kept telling us it would only be another 5 minutes, but then an hour went by. The manager was apologetic though, and gave us three free appetizers and wine. Definitely made up for the rough start. 

The food itself was very good. The appetizers that were comped for us were all great selections. For the main, I ordered a the scallops. Kind of wish there had been more variation on the plate, but the scallops were cooked well and tasted good. 

Restaurant overall is a bit loud though, and at times it was hard to hear/talk with the people I came to dine with.

photos.caption: Appetizers - bread and cheese plate + falafel

comment.text: One of the best tasting menus I've ever had. Every dish was balanced, and it was not too much not too little food. Plus amazing wine pairing (a gamay). Only wish I lived in Atlanta to go back,

Went for dinner, and enjoyed the experience and food, except for a weird decision by the restaurant. Bread was $3 per person at the table. I get it if you want to charge for bread, but charging everyone at the table even if they don't want bread, "just in case that person may eat a piece of bread" seems petty and cheap for a $220 dinner bill. I know it seems petty on my side, but it sticks in my craw and took away from the experience.

My new favorite date night spot! The service is top notch and the food was delicious. My evening here exceeded all my expectations. 
I am for sure coming back again!

Aria is a very upscale, 'special occasion' type place.  And since this was our anniversary, it seemed appropriate. 

We made a reservation a few weeks in advance, though I don't know how quickly they fill up.  We arrived a bit before our 6:30 p.m. time slot.  Parking is valet, which is probably for the best as they appear to have a small lot.

The ambiance is dark/intimate.  If you enter during daylight, it takes a minute to adjust to the lack of interior lighting initially.  The dining room is a bit brighter.  We were shown to our table on what was apparently 'anniversary row', as the 3 tables all eventually featured couples who were celebrating theirs.  

The wait staff is all similarly uniformed and is very polished.  They know the menu, wines, drinks, etc. cold.  Even given the general price point of this place, the by-the-glass wine prices were noticeably high.  We opted to split a salad (which was still a hearty portion for each of us).  My wife had one of the fish options and I had the steak, which was quite good.  We split a dessert, which was also good.  

Prices here are steep, but that shouldn't be a surprise given the overall quality of the food / service / atmosphere. If you're looking for someplace to make an impression, this is a good choice.

This was our second time to Aria. 

We went for our anniversary four years ago and sat in the cellar for a special evening that didn't disappoint - aside from the ambiance, which was obviously top-notch, the service and food presented Aria very well. 

For my 30th birthday, we decided to go back to Aria as a way of celebrating this important birthday through one of our old favorite restaurants. Unfortunately, we collectively regretted this decision for the following reasons:

1). Many of the items from the menu that we ordered came to the table with ingredients missing. For example, per the menu, the salad should have had roasted corn on it, or the sashimi should have had green apple in it. For them not to mention specific items missing before bringing dishes to the table is not good service. I would even hold Cheesecake Factory to this standard of service.

Order:

Starters:
Chickpea Fritters
Sashimi
Avocado + Corn Salad 

Entree:
Scallops
Short Rib

Side: 
Lobster Mashed Potatoes


2). The scallop dish left me confused. The scallops themselves were cooked well. Aside from that, the rest of the dish lacked purpose. The "sauce" was extremely bland (just tasted like a watered-down butter) and the squash was undercooked. In my opinion it was missing an acid (i.e. citrus, tomatoes, vinegar, etc.) and salt, but really any pop of flavor would do this dish well.  Overall, I found myself underwhelmed and perplexed as to if this was how the dish was supposed to be prepared. 
Similarly, the Lobster Mashed Potatoes lacked a lot of flavor. I think it could've used more butter, salt, and pepper. We ended up asking for parmesan cheese to add some flavor to the potatoes and that improved it a bit. In any case, a restaurant of this caliber shouldn't be missing on the flavor element.

3). While the service was generally fine, the server did not address that it was my birthday till the end of dinner, almost as if he had forgot or wasn't told until the last minute. We've dined at all of the top restaurants in ATL for our birthdays and this was probably handled the worst. 

I'm not sure what's changed here between our visits but genuinely hope that this helps improve areas of weakness.

Had a delicious meal here. Made a reservation at 8:15 we were seated right away but the place was packed so a reservation is highly recommended on the weekends for dinner. They complementary valet parking so no need to worry about parking. 

We stared with the arugula salad which was good. Next we went with the octopus dish and the lump  crab cake. The lump crab cake was the highlight very well executed adding the salad with it, the amount of saltiness was perfect. The octopus was good too but not as good as the crab.

For our main dishes we went with the snapper filet and the mountain trout. Again both were great but liked the snapper more. .

Finally finished off with apple tart. It was good but nothing special.

Here are my ratings:
Arugula salad: 8/10
Octopus: 8/10
Crab cake: 8.5/10
Mountain trout: 8/10
Snapper filet: 8.5/10
Apple tart: 7.5/10

This place is top notch from servers to ambience to food. The only fall back was the dessert, it had no wow factor in it.  The mushroom soup was ok I guess not to our liking but maybe that's coz of our taste buds, we probably not used to wild mushrooms soup.  
The entrees were delicious and so was the presentation.

We had an impressive and fun Saturday dinner here. The space is upscale and stylish (most people were dressed up) but the service is warm and unobtrusive. Highlights for me were the crab cake starter served over a Vietnamese-style salad and the Brussels sprouts side, which was served with the filet (a perfect medium rare). There was plenty on the menu we'd look forward to trying on our next visit. I thought the broccoli side (served with the pork) was a bit bland, and I'd probably try the short rib over the pork next time around.

I was also impressed with the restaurant's COVID measures. A lot of places have let those fall by the wayside, but tables here were very well spaced out, and the staff all wore masks and gave you your space. 

Will definitely return on future visits to Buckhead!

I always heard this place being compared to Canoe. I love love Canoe so I decided to check this place out. The difference is uncanny. The portions were tiny and the food was barely okay. For the price I paid, I could've had my fill and then some at other places for similar quality. 

Food:
The lobster entree/ tiny half of a tail on top of cold mash potatoes and sauce.
The duck entree/ two pieces of salty meat with beans.
A salad to share/ only good thing we had. House-made croutons and crisp veggies. The radish slices added a nice burst of flavor.

Dessert: a variety of house-made sorbets -that was highly recommended by my server cuz my friend doesn't like overly sweet desserts. But these were all so sour! They all tasted similar and just overbearingly sour! No unique pops of flavors. Sorbets should be a nice balance of sweet and sour but these were just awfully sour with barely enough fruit sauce to sweeten it. They had a merengue chip on the bottom but that didn't compliment the flavors at all and was just too sweet. I was so upset! Dessert is always the last thing you remember from a meal and I'm left with a sour memory!

photos.caption: Salad split. One of the best parts of the meal
Very small lobster... ate it in 2 bites
Very salty duck on a bed of beans
Best part of the meal. Three little pieces of warm bread
Sorbet. All tasted the same and so so sour

comment.text: We tried the tasting menu and it was a fabulous experience. We also enjoyed the wine pairing.

user.name: Natii N.
user.address: Río Piedras, San Juan, Puerto Rico

comment.text: Beautiful place but food is not impressive at all. Very overpriced. Great desserts though. I would try someone else if you are looking for a great fine dinning option

The food can be fantastic and 5 stars, but also fair and 3 Stars.

Service is the same, up and down.

Hit or miss so be prepared..

We do love the Foie Gras most times...

We found this place  when looking for a place to celebrate a special occasion and even when we live here, we decided to go for a recommendation from trip advisor for one of the most romantic places in Atlanta.  

The place is a small modern and cozy restaurant.   The environment is dimmed light and  tonight's crowd was either larger groups,  over 10 people, or several tables with couples.  

They change their menu, according to our server every day, so if I get the names wrong, I'm sorry :).  We started with drinks, I cannot drink so I had a virgin mojito and the hubby had an apple martini that looked very tasty and according to him it was as good as it looked. Tonight we had as an appetizer the crispy pork belly and the braised beef, both of them were very good, however, against what I usually like, the pork belly was superior.  As entrees we  chose the short ribs of beef and the scallops. This place specialty is the braised meats, so as you can imagine the short ribs were DELICIOUS!  Finally, we were celebrating so why not go also for dessert right? We had the brown butter and caramel cake, and to not lose track of the experience,  it matched the amazing flavor.

photos.caption: Brown butter and caramel cake with malt ice cream
